quoteFirst: The area of the state was about 983 square kilometers (equivalent to 379.5 sq. mi. or 242,899 acres).[486] Estimating the population of this agricultural community at its maximum of sixty to the square kilometer, we should have less than 60,000 for the entire area.[487] The number of men from
quoteLast: ty, the Roman military age, should be about thirty per cent of the population[488]—less therefore than 18,000. If the ratio of juniors to seniors was about three to one,[489] we should have about 13,000 juniors to 5000 seniors.
title: The Roman assemblies from their origin to the end of the Republic
author: Botsford, George Willis, 1862-1917

quoteFirst: She had nine children and about forty grandchildren. At one time, she had lived with her husband, the deacon, in a poor village; she had lived there a very long time from the age of
quoteLast: ty. The bishop remembered her from early childhood, almost from the age of three, and--how he had loved her! Sweet, precious childhood, always fondly remembered! Why did it, that long-past time that could never return, why did it seem brighter, fuller, and more festive than it had really been? When in his childhood or youth he had been ill, how tender and sympathetic his mother had been! And now his prayers mingled with the memories, which gleamed more and more brightly like a flame, and the prayers did not hinder his thinking of his mother.
title: The Bishop and Other Stories
author: Chekhov, Anton Pavlovich, 1860-1904; Garnett, Constance, 1861-1946 [Translator]

quoteFirst: They beat the Con Men yesterday by
title: Right off the Bat: Baseball Ballads
author: Kirk, William Frederick, 1877-1927; Martin, H. B. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: For example, one of this year’s publications announces that “Dog Days” begin on the 21st of July, and end on the 30th of August, making, as we see by including one extreme date, altogether the forty days claimed by the ancients. But in this latitude, on the former date, the star rises at
quoteLast: , one hour and five minutes _after_, and on the latter date at 3:06 a. m., two hours and twenty minutes _before_ sunrise.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, July 1884, No. 10
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: The most careless must have observed the increase in the amount of daylight in the northern hemisphere since the 21st of last December. On the first of the present month the sun rises at
quoteLast: and sets at 6:25 p. m.; on the 30th it rises at 4:59 a. m. and sets at 6:55 p. m., so that the increase in “day’s length,” as we are accustomed to call it, will be one hour and seven minutes.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 04, April 1884, No. 7
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: These notes must, therefore, be taken only as hints, and the reader may be interested to know that they are based on the observation of sixty-five women, subdivided as follows: Intimate acquaintance, five; adequate acquaintance, nineteen; slight acquaintance, forty-one; married, thirty-nine; status uncertain, eight; celibate, eighteen. Ages,
title: The Intelligence of Woman
author: George, Walter Lionel, 1882-1926

quoteFirst: Did the numbers given designate all the citizens, or only the heads of families, or those who had attained the age of puberty? In my opinion, these numbers in Livy, Dionysius of Halicarnassus, and Plutarch, applied to all the men in a condition to carry arms, that is, according to the organisation of Servius Tullius, to those from
quoteLast: ty years old. This category formed, in fact, the true Roman citizens. Under seventeen, they were too young to count in the State; above sixty, they were too old.
title: History of Julius Cæsar, Vol. 1 of 2
author: Napoleon III, Emperor of the French, 1808-1873

quoteFirst: 80,000 men in condition to carry arms represent, according to the statistics of the present time, fifty-five hundredths of the male part of the population, say 145,000 men, and for the two sexes, supposing them equal in number, 290,000 souls. In fact, in France, in a hundred inhabitants, there are 35 who have not passed the age of seventeen, 55 aged from
quoteLast: ty years, and 10 of more than sixty.
title: History of Julius Cæsar, Vol. 1 of 2
author: Napoleon III, Emperor of the French, 1808-1873

quoteFirst: As he is an evening star, the most convenient opportunities are afforded for obtaining a fine view. He rises on the 1st at 3:07 p. m., and sets on the 2nd at
quoteLast: ; on the 15th rises at 2:04 p. m., and sets the following morning at 4:40; on the 30th, rises at 1:07 p. m., and sets on the 31st at 3:43 a. m.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, January 1885, No. 4
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: She had nine children and about forty grandchildren. At one time, she had lived with her husband, the deacon, in a poor village; she had lived there a very long time from the age of
quoteLast: ty. The bishop remembered her from early childhood, almost from the age of three, and--how he had loved her! Sweet, precious childhood, always fondly remembered! Why did it, that long-past time that could never return, why did it seem brighter, fuller, and more festive than it had really been? When in his childhood or youth he had been ill, how tender and sympathetic his mother had been! author: Chekhov, Anton Pavlovich, 1860-1904; Widger, David, 1932-2021? [Editor]

quoteFirst: Meantime, finite beings are interested in knowing how its light and heat affect their interests, and how these qualities may be made most profitable to mankind. For ourselves, we must at present be content to know that on the 1st our sun has reached a point 4° 48′ north of the equator, and that by the 30th he will be 14° 58′ north, an increase in northern declination of 10° 10′, and, as a consequence, our daylight will be increased about one hour and thirteen minutes, and the time “from early dawn to dewy” twilight will be seventeen hours and thirty-five minutes. On the 1st sunrise occurs at
quoteLast: , sunset, 6:24 p. m.; on the 16th, sunrise, 5:19, sunset, 6:40; on the 30th, sunrise, 4:59, sunset, 6:54.
title: The Chautauquan, Vol. 05, April 1885
author: Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle; Chautauqua Institution; Flood, Theodore L., 1842- [Editor]

quoteFirst: I don't know in all this miserable world a more miserable spectacle than that of a young fellow of five or six and forty. The British army, that nursery of valour, turns out many of the young fellows I mean: who, having flaunted in dragoon uniforms from
quoteLast: -and-thirty; having bought, sold, or swapped during that period some two hundred horses; having played, say, fifteen thousand games at billiards; having drunk some six thousand bottles of wine; having consumed a reasonable number of Nugee coats, split many dozen pairs of high-heeled Hoby boots, and read the newspaper and the army-list duly, retire from the service when they have attained their eighth lustre, and saunter through the world, trailing from London to Cheltenham, and from Boulogne to Paris, and from Paris to Baden, their idleness, their ill-health, and their
title: Catherine: A Story
author: Thackeray, William Makepeace, 1811-1863
